README.md.message: Since there are five seats, what would be super majority in this case? 3 or 4 votes? It may be useful to have a specific number of votes to be specified e.g. 4/5 instead of fractions.

5*2/3 = 3.(3). Basically, super majority (2/3) is 3 votes out of 5.
For the "Disputes Across Committees" section that would be (5+5)*2/3=6.(6), so 7 votes out of 10 are required. This is my understanding.

Correct. As committee sizes change a 2/3 vote will always be used.  However 2/3 of 10 would have to be rounded up to 7 as you cannot have 6.6 people vote.

I will add a snippet clarifying this point that 2/3 is considered rounded up to nearest whole number.

networking_calico/etcdv3.py.message: Will we get an exception if the request is denied, for example?  Just wondering if anything could make response['token'] unsafe.

Yes, we do, and there's a case that our test code hits: when reauthenticating because the previous token has expired, we get an exception here because the etcd server objects to the presence of an Authorization header with the old token on the /auth/authenticate request.

The fix is to remove Authorization from self.session.headers before sending the /auth/authenticate request.

I haven't yet seen this issue with our product code (i.e. the mechanism driver or DHCP agent).  I think the reason is it takes 5 minutes for a normal token to expire, and using the token refreshes it.  (Ref: https://github.com/etcd-io/etcd/issues/8287)  Product code is doing stuff all the time, so the token probably never expires.  But our test can go for more than 5 minutes without sending a request to etcd itself.

Nevertheless I think I should apply the fix for that here (as well as in the test code's copy of this code).

More generally, if there is an exception raised here, I think it's OK for it to bubble up.  That should be equivalent to the original post() call raising an exception, and we have existing handling for that (e.g. for connectivity failure) in the various callers.
If the watch loop bypasses post, what happens if the token expires while we're watching?
I've reviewed that we are OK here, and have commented about that in the next patchset.

According to the discussion at https://github.com/etcd-io/etcd/issues/8287#issuecomment-316591317, token expiration does not affect an existing watch, so long as the watch _began_ when the token was still valid.

As discussed, probably some corner-case scenarios where this might come into play so please can you make sure that, when a watch fails, that always triggers a new post.  I think it's likely that our watch loop does a new get when a watch fails but it'd be good to make sure.

Couple of scenarios I can think of: etcd failover; VM gets paused and restarted mid-watch.
Can we tell if this is an auth-related exception?

Think we' agreed that you'd rework to avoid trying an authed request if we don't have username/password (so you can re-raise the original exception and avoid obscuring the cause of the failure on a non-authed system)
Yes, that's done now, in the next patchset.

OK, I've found the source for those errors now at https://github.com/etcd-io/etcd/blob/master/etcdserver/api/v3rpc/rpctypes/error.go.  The first is ErrGRPCUserEmpty and the second ErrGRPCInvalidAuthToken/.  But still not sure if it would be a good idea to test on (code in [3, 16])...

Indeed; I wanted to be more targeted here, but have not been able to establish how reliable or specific the currently observed response details are.  Currently, for a request with no authorization, when auth is enabled, we see:

400 Bad Request with content:
{"error":"etcdserver: user name is empty","code":3}

and for a request with authorization that has expired we see

401 Unauthorized with content:
{"error":"etcdserver: invalid auth token","code":16}

I haven't yet found an authoritative source for those 3 and 16 codes, and I don't know if we can rely on those codes or messages staying the same.

I'll try again to find the source for those codes; but what would you advise?
This could be too low for a snapshot read, especially if it's through a slow proxy server (think a customer got caught out by that before)
Thanks; config parameter added in patchset 5, defaulting to 60s.

Eesh, we're relying on our caller here to make sure that instance.host is the correct thing. I guess you're trying to minimize collateral damage for backportability, but what about changing this to something like teardown_on = host, activate_on = host? I realize we'd have to change all the callers but it seems like it would make the code a bit clearer...

> Eesh, we're relying on our caller here to make sure that
 > instance.host is the correct thing.

Yup, which can get a bit gross e.g.:

https://review.opendev.org/#/c/637630/48/nova/compute/manager.py@4560

 > I guess you're trying to
 > minimize collateral damage for backportability,

I guess, but this has been sitting so long I'm not sure I'd backport it anyway. I think it was more about not having to make major changes to the interface.

 > but what about
 > changing this to something like teardown_on = host, activate_on =
 > host? I realize we'd have to change all the callers but it seems
 > like it would make the code a bit clearer...

That might work. I'm not sure it would be all the callers. If teardown_on defaults to None then it's still Falsey and anything not tearing down doesn't change, only cases where callers are passing teardown=True.

And activate_on is only 2 call sites right now for rolling back a live migration. The other call site would be in my cross-cell resize series here:

https://review.opendev.org/#/c/637630/48/nova/compute/manager.py@4551

Overall this method has turned into a monster because it does the port migration profile stuff which for neutron only matters if DVR is involved, which is probably not the majority of deployments these days. But we're also using this method for other things, and we also have migrate_instance_start/finish, and setup_instance_network_on_host which is also confusing since sounds a lot like this method (setup_networks_on_host). Hell for that matter we also have cleanup_instance_network_on_host which for neutron is a no-op today.

So other options that don't involve messing with this method at all would be:

1. Doing like https://review.opendev.org/#/c/637630/48/nova/compute/manager.py@4547 by mutating the migration set dest_compute=source_compute and call migrate_instance_start. But that mutation sucks since it bleeds / couples the internals of how that method works.

2. Write a new method that's not so fucking dumb and just call it active_port_bindings_on_host(instance, host) and let the caller determine what to pass in without the migration object. That's much more straight forward. migrate_instance_start could also be changed to use that.

The downside to either of the above options is the caller still has to make two calls, one to activate on the source and one to teardown on the dest (the call to this method setup_networks_on_host). Maybe that's fine, I mean that's what this change is already doing, but it's doing it in one place and arguably making this already complicated method do even more complicated stuff.

Maybe a way to solve that complication is to stack a change on top which is a convenience method for this 2-call operation where teardown_host= and activate_host= kwargs determine what to do and then that method calls active_port_bindings_on_host and setup_networks_on_host under the covers.

It would be a bigger win if we could do a bulk query for info about all the *ports* at once.  If possible, it would mean hoisting the bulk query out of this routine and doing it in _build_network_info_model().

Yeah, I'm not sure how many fixed IPs we have on a single port anyway, plus this appears to not be working since there is a tempest test failing on this change. I'll probably push a change to do it this way and the old way and compare results, and log an error if they are different, meaning this bulk query doesn't work.

nova/compute/manager.py.message: TODO: should probably leave a reminder to add something to nova-status for this. It would basically be the same DB query except for the specific instance UUIDs.

Two issues here:

1. We should get this once outside the loop.

2. Should we use the original host connector used to create the initial backend storage connection? If the attachment is new enough, the original host connector is stashed in the connection_info in the BDM and we can try to re-use that first before relying on the current host connector. See how the 'local delete' flow in the API handles this:

https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/2ec8c49f6cb4a0e7dba217e824c20d9c703d2105/nova/compute/api.py#L1994

If we start up all our computes at the same time post-upgrade, like you would expect config management to do, we're going to storm cinder's castle pretty hard. Surely some of these will fail and then we'll bail out of this method, which will kill startup. That means each compute will have to re-spawn nova-compute to make some more progress, which might fail again. If it happens enough, systemd might stop respawning for a while, etc.

Wouldn't it be better to be super graceful about any cinder-related failures and pause for a minute or so before continuing (related also to my comment below about using a thread for this).

Yeah I can catch an error and sleep for a second or something, unless you think we need a longer sleep.

Alternatively to this, I think at some point I had mentioned running this in a periodic task, like heal_instance_info which works on a queue of instances, one per minute. But the problem with that is eventually you'd done the migration and don't need that periodic task running every minute just to query the database and do nothing. The operator could disable it when they're done, but that's not cool either.

Yeah I think making it a one-shot task on startup is probably okay, and it can just exit when it's sure there's nothing to do. I don't know that a periodic is necessarily a problem either, as it can short-circuit itself to off just like the task can exit. Unless you're worried about debug log-spam about running it?

I think it's easier to reason about a one-shot background thread, but either would be okay with me, FWIW.
When we did the ironic flavor resource class migration thing, we spawned this a a thread on startup. Seems like make it would be worth doing the same thing here?
Sure I can thread this out.
Do we want to retry? If not, we're going to be left with a single (or multiple, if this failed multiple times) BDM that doesn't have this attribute set, while everything else does

We'll retry next time the nova-compute service is restarted, which I think is good enough. I imagine we'll eventually have an online data migration check in nova-manage for these before we can actually drop the old code flows, but that's not something we'll be doing in Rocky anyway, so this is here for people rolling through.

I think we might have one or two issues with this, but need to verify:

centos_srpms_centos.lst.message: Does it mean if I upgraded some of the basic rpms, like rabbitmq, I need to update every .lst file using these rpms?
For rpm, how do I know which layer should the rpm belong to?

Yes, it's a picky question. It request developer have a more deep understanding about buildrequire and require.

For example, if you want to upgrade src rpm, and the new version introduce new built-required or required package, check src rpm for which project in .repo/manifests/*.xml, distro.xml, flock.xml or compile.xml. then add rpm to stx-tools/centos-mirror-tool/config/centos/layer/*.lst

If upgrade source rpm, declare in centos_srpms_centos.lst in its project. For build require and required rpm. Add in stx-tools/centos-mirror-tools/config/centos/<layer>/rpms_centos.lst. stx-tools/centos-mirror-tools/rpms_centos.lst will be removed.

not only that, current way of running tempest (at least on DevStack) is still inside a virtualenv.

Tempest tests are API only, so there should not be any difference what Python are they running under compared to the API services.

Correct, this change will allow projects that wish to drop py2 to be able to only track the py3 requirements so as more and more dependencies drop py2, wish is going to start happening a lot, we won't constantly be breaking everyone's gate when we add caps that don't apply to them.

Yeah, so for context we added separate caps for Sphinx on Python 2 and Python 3, and the result was that every repo had to update doc/requirements.txt, even though almost all repos are running docs on Python 3 only, otherwise their requirements job was broken.

Without this change, we'd be facing the same problem but on a massive scale as large numbers of projects switched to Python 3 only (so they don't care about Python 2 caps) while large numbers of dependencies did the same (thus requiring separate caps in global requirements to support projects like Swift that are not dropping Python 2).

It's the projects *not* keeping py2 support that would break without this. (They'd break because Oslo is also switching to python3-only, so we will need separate v2/v3 caps for Oslo - in the same way we already have for Sphinx - to enable Swift to keep using Oslo in python2.)

What are you attempting to fail? This should always succeed. It's a bit redundant with the allow_3_only default, but I felt it was better to have an explicit test to validate that the behavior was no different for those that choose not to remove the py2 entries.

I misunderstood what it was checking.  I was expecting that if I changed ``allow_3_only=True`` to False it'd fail (and the other test does.   Then I thought it'd fail if the py2 requirements were different between the project and global_reqs.  But neither of these cause failures.

So the point is to show that even on branches where py3_only is OK having py2 requirements wont cause requirements-check to fail.  Correct?

yeah, doc/requirements.txt is main candidate for this due to sphinx req. Projects keeping py2 support keep having py27 requirement also which will match g-r because nobody will change those requirements for py27 in projects requirements file.

Actually, I just realised this isn't sufficient. If python3-only projects have to update their requirements.txt from:

  name>=1.5

to

  name>=1.5;python_version>='3.5'

then that's still a change that will require ~every project to update their requirements.txt to avoid breakage. What we really want is for it to still work when this line is just:

  name>=1.5
Yeah, probably good to have that test coverage. Updated.

Oh, good :)

It would be nice if we had a test to check that.

That last case will still work. If there is no specific python_version, then the requirement will be checked and it will expect it to be present in both local requirements and global-requirements. The evaluation only happens when a python_version is provided, then there is a check that the given version matches the provided runtime version.

We could actually raise that provided runtime version to 3.6, but I didn't think we wanted to go that far.

I meant we should test without this bit (I tried and it fails).

The situation we want to handle is where both the project's requirements.txt and the global-requirements list currently have:

  some-dep>=1.0

and now we're going to cap the python2 dep, so global-requirements changes to:

  some-dep>=1.0;python_version>='3.6'
  some-dep>=1.0,<=2.0;python_version=='2.7'

we want this to Just Work without *any* changes to the project's requirements.txt.

As it stands we would have to update every project's requirements.txt to:

  some-dep>=1.0;python_version>=3.6

which is better than having to also add the pointless py27 line as well, but not nearly as good as not having to update every project at all.

pip has been stupid in the past and specifying python 3 as well prevents us from shooting ourselves in the foot, personally I prefer Zane's version, though once py2 is FULLY dropped we could switch to the simple version.

I agree, it would be good if we didn't have to have the py3 markers included. We can try to test that for a future patch, but I think that will take a bit more refactoring. And we will need to try various version of pip to make sure it gets handled right with all supported versions out there.

I think we only need to add the python2 version cap not py3 but not sure it that conflict from requirement installation?

  some-dep>=1.0

TO

  some-dep>=1.0
  some-dep>=1.0,<=2.0;python_version=='2.7'

neutron/quota/resource_registry.py.message: the CONTEXT_WRITER.using() statement below does not begin a nested transaction, it only affirms that a transaction is in progress if one was not already.   is it possible this comment was left over from before neutron was converted to enginefacade?

I'm not sure this should be removed.   if set_resources_dirty is called directly from a function that did not establish a transaction, then this will fail.   The db_api.CONTEXT_WRITER.using(context) acts as only an assertion that a transaction is in play, assuming one is in progress already.

OTOH if you would like this function to actively fail if it is called from outside of an existing DB transaction then this can be left off.

but in either case enginefacade doesn't do "nested" transactions unless you tell it to do so explicitly.

Hmm, I thought db_api.CONTEXT_WRITER.using(context) will start a transaction is one is not active. mark_dirty() below is decorated with retry_if_session_inactive - which will fail if transaction is in progress.

Also why would one start a transaction inside a for loop?

I think I wasn't clear and my use of the word "assert" is inaccurate.    the "db_api.CONTEXT_WRITER.using(context)" does this:

1. if there is no DB transaction started, it starts one.

2. if there *is* a DB transaction started, it passes silently.

that's all it does.   there's no "nested" transaction, which is something that used to be the case before the enginefacade was used.
Indeed, set_resources_dirty is always called from inside a transaction, I missed that somehow. So the patch is wrong in its current state. I'll redo. Thanks Michael.

I think this is fine.    If there is already a DB transaction in play, then this just passes without doing anything.  if there is not a DB transaction in play, it starts one.  I'm assuming the res.mark_dirty() call requires a DB transaction.  I don't think it would interfere with a retry decorator outside.

    - name: allocate hugepages
      shell: echo 512 >
/sys/kernel/mm/hugepages/hugepages-2048kB/nr_hugepages
      become: yes

- hosts: subnode
  tasks:
    - name: allocate hugepages
      shell: echo 2048 >
/sys/kernel/mm/hugepages/hugepages-2048kB/nr_hugepages
      become: yes

that will allocate 512*2mb (1GB) of hugepages on the contoler nodes

and 2048*2MB(4G) of hugepages on the subnode groups which is the compute nodes.


when you allocate via sys/kernel/mm/hugepages/hugepages-2048kB/nr_hugepages
rather then the per numa node way the kernel is free to balance the allcoation as it sees fit but typeicaly it will blance them evnely across all numa nodes.

The intent is to replace the wiki pages for the Feature and Defect processes. Re: the organization - there are overlaps between the two processes and my intent was to cover those in one place, but that's not as clear as it could be. Will work to improve it.
I see IRC as a tool for discussions/questions. The mailing list should be the primary tool for announcements/notifications.
My preference is that the mailing list is the primary method of notification. IRC is likely better for live discussions as opposed to notifications.

This makes more sense for larger changes such as features/enhancements. I'm not sure it's necessary to notify the community when starting to work on a bug (unless the developer is requesting technical input).
For features, where does the spec posting/review/approval cycle fit in? Often times, the spec will be needed before starting to modify code.

Larger features require specs. This needs to be documented as part of this process. Larger changes can also span sub-projects.

Specs are mentioned below but conflicts with the documented workflow here.

This is just the process to submit a feature request. It could be done by an end-user who has no intention of developing the feature. The process needs a method to gather user feedback and right now we have no other method.
What about the feature review process that happens at the beginning of a release cycle at the PTG and the engagement with the TSC?  Shouldn't this be documented somewhere in this section?
Changed this to a reference to the Planning phase which has a full description of the process.

To me, this implies that people can suggest features without necessarily bringing any resources to contribute to them. Most openstack projects expect you to staff features you propose; this makes them more likely to be accepted/prioritized. If a feature is important to somebody, they should be willing to staff it (at least partially). I suggest you re-word this to make this expectation clearer.

Allowing users to submit feature requests without staffing the work is a desired feature, IMO since we have no other formal way to capture end user feedback.  I've changed the text to more strongly recommend that feature submissions are much more likely to be implemented if the submitter helps work on them.
Which part of the triage is of the most concern? Adding the sub-project tag or adding the release tag/priority?

Adding the tags is not the concern.  Discussing the impact of a bug and the possible root causes out in the open is a good learning activity for anyone who is new to the community and code base. It's also an important part of a dev process that is fully open.

The previous concern was that reviewing bugs on a weekly or bi-weekly basis was not frequent enough. Right now, I am currently reviewing 3 times a week. I'm happy to schedule public meetings if that's what the community wants (but I have no available time slots in the morning which will make it hard for the PLs from China to attend)

I agree that the logistics here are hard. I'm pretty sure that if we ask the community to answer honestly, most people would say that bug scrubs are not one of their favorite things. But moving the bug review out into the open (somehow) remains a key goal, I think. Maybe we could leverage time left over in the community meeting and do as much as we could in the time available each week?  Not sure what to do here but would like to see the workload reduced and spread more within the community.

The generation of the overrides is stripping it because it will do validation on the addresses prior to wrapping it (adding brackets). This occurs to me a bit late since we're doing this before a resize_claim for resize and cold migrate, but if this modifies the instance.pci_requests and the claim below fails, the instance.pci_requests are not rolled back and would be wrong, correct? What would break after that if the user tries to recover the instance by doing something like hard-rebooting it?

Good point. The InstancePciRequest is updated here but that update is not reverted if the operation is rolled back. 

The parent_ifname piece of information in the pci request is like trait, it only driver the selection of the proper VF pools during the pci_claim. It does not cause the consumption of the PF. The VF consumption done by the pci_claim is rolled back when the move_claim is aborted.

After the rollback the wrong information is still persisted in the InstancePciRequest (it still uses the parent_ifname for the failed dest host). It is ugly but I think it does not cause any failure later on. Every new move operation updates (will update as soon as it support move with qos ports) the InstancePciRequest according to the destination host before calling move_claim. So when the new pci_claim is triggered the valid parent_ifname will be present in the pci request. 

I checked the callers of pci_claim to see if other lifecycle operations use calls that:
* rt.instance_claim is called from build_and_run_instance and unshelve. The build does not apply here as this instance already built. The unshelve will be handled when I add support for qos ports in unshelve.

* rt._move_claim is called from live_migration_claim, rebuild_claim, resize_claim. The resize_claim is already handled in Train, except for cross cell resize. I need to handle that in Ussuri. The live_migration will be handled in Ussuri. The rebuild_claim is used only during evacuate which is handled in this patch.

I will check how hard it is to roll back the InstancePciRequest change but I think it would need either a way to store the original parent_ifname somewhere to re-query it from placement.

> I will check how hard it is to roll back the InstancePciRequest
 > change but I think it would need either a way to store the original
 > parent_ifname somewhere to re-query it from placement.

Sounds like maybe something we could stash in the instance migration_context if we get past the claim (which creates the migration_context) and use that later to rollback if needed.

I guess this method isn't too expensive, it's just building a dict to return, but this is the second time this is called since _do_rebuild_instance_with_claim calls it as well and we could just pass those results down here, but it's a nit.

oslo_utils/strutils.py.message: Can be more safer to leave that in the case where someone re add some uppercase keys in the future...
Good idea. Thanks Cedric for doing the update!

I'm half tempted to suggest we just add 'key' as a key since a lot of these include that. That's so broad though. :-/

It's just that this is essentially doubling the number of keys we need to check each time, and most of them are highly TripleO-specific. I don't know if that will have a meaningful performance impact, but it would be interesting to profile a service before and after this change.

We've historically tried really hard to avoid that. So far successfully. :-)

The reason being that we want the behavior across projects to be consistent, and if projects are able to add their own custom keys then you can end up in a weird situation where something gets sanitized in one project but not another. Even if we did make this list extensible, you've still got the problem that the list has to live in Mistral even if it's TripleO-specific so you still have the same problem on a smaller scale, and now the inconsistency problem too.

So I guess the TLDR is that I don't want to do that unless someone provides hard numbers that show this is causing an unacceptable performance problem in other services.
Makes sense, that sounds like good reasoning. Thanks.
I had wondered about this too. Another option would be to make it configurable? Then we can only take the hit for the more obscure keys that we need.

Small note as for "use key as a key":
- the current way strings are matched will break, especially for xml and json.
While "non-xml/non-json" will match if key ends with "key", we might have some risk in masking unrelated things. Thus I tend to be against this simplification.

I'm not going to block this on something that might be premature optimization, but I'd like to see the key list pre-processed when the list is created so we aren't doing this lower() operation on every key every time this gets called. It's pretty inefficient to do this in the inner loop.

I think we can do both. Leave the existing list as-is, then create a new one:

_LOWER_SANITIZE_KEYS = [k.lower() for k in _SANITIZE_KEYS]

Then use that new list for this loop. If someone accidentally adds an uppercase key to the hard-coded list, it gets handled appropriately, but we don't have to do the lower a huge number of times.

Honestly, there should be unit tests added for new keys that would catch if someone incorrectly capitalized one, but I realize we're not perfect about test coverage so I'm fine with the belt-and-suspenders approach.
I lowered the list in the patch. Note adminPass and CHAPPASSWORD changed. I had removed the lower() here but was asked to put it back in as a precaution on a previous patchset
Sounds good. I can go ahead and do that.

I should have thought about that, sorry -.-'.
+1 for a pre-processing, especially since we're doing it twice.

src/reactive/vault_handlers.py.message: So, Im not familiar with this config object. What does it returns in max-ttl if the user does not set? The default value?

This may be called automatically on deployments if "auto-generate-root-ca-cert" is enabled. The ttl and max-ttl values read by this function as-is are not configurable, as the values are hardcoded in actions.yaml.

there isn't a config named "ttl". This should be "default-ttl". I am testing a scenario where the customer may want to change the default-lease, and by changing this "ttl" to "default-ttl" then every time config-changed hook is run, it runs this function and updates the leases. Therefore, new certificates that are issued directly through vault without specifying the TTL use the new default-value.

The current "config.set.ttl" value prevents this method from being run as this condition is never true.

nova/tests/fixtures.py.message:
This fixture is a common part of testing, and this additional code is just for Windows. However this workaround(catching ImportError) is too generic. I think the workaround can make potential issues disappear in long-term.

How about switching the behavior on TestCase side instead?
TBH, I am still not sure what is actual error you want to fix.
It is better to submit launchpad report to share that and include the report number in the commit message.

The issue is that nova.virt.libvirt is not importable on Windows: http://paste.openstack.org/raw/628147/ The culprit seems to be the 'pwd' module, which is not available on Windows.

We know that at the moment, running all the Nova unit tests on Windows may not be possible (similar import errors are highly likely to occur), but we'd like to at least be able to run the Hyper-V driver unit tests on Windows.

I don't think we can do anything at the TestCase level, besides skipping this fixture, but I wouldn't do that as it may be helpful on Windows as well.

IMO catching this import error isn't that bad. Even if it passes here, if there's something preventing that module from being imported, the according unit tests should fail. If really needed, we may add a platform check here.

The alternative would be to add platform checks at the libvirt module level but I don't think that the libvirt driver maintainers would be too happy about that.

I do agree that this could use a bug report though.

nova/network/neutronv2/api.py.message: Need to add unit tests for when this isn't None.
The problem is that when attaching a port, this networks is a subset of the fields of...

...this networks which comes from neutron. So we lose the anything that is later needed in _nw_info_build_network or anything it calls later, like _get_physnet_tunneled_info.

I can at least see these fields missing:

- mtu
- segments
- provider:physical_network
- provider:network_type
I'm lost a bit. The extra 'network' parameter is added to use a cached network but here if the 'network' is cached fall back to re-fetch it.

> The extra 'network' parameter is added to use a cached network

Not really "cached" but "in scope" meaning we already got the network by id from the port earlier in the call stack and could just pass it down here.

The issue noted here is if we've attached a port, in that case we're rebuilding the cache from the cache for potentially part of it, e.g. let's say I create the server on network A and port A is created. Then I attach a port from network B. When rebuilding the cache during attach from network B, we'll re-use the nw info cache data for network A which comes from _gather_port_ids_and_networks and doesn't have fields in it like mtu, segments, provider:physical_network, etc. It only has id, name and tenant_id.

My brain exploded while I tried to see how '_network' and 'network' is used below.

Do we need to use 'network' at all below if '_network' has the same value anyhow?

I know it's confusing, I'm open to suggestions. The issue is this method potentially calls show_network twice and I wanted to avoid calling it at all of the original network passed in is not None. One could say we could just get the _network the first time and use it the second time, but the fields wouldn't be there on the second usage (the first show_network only gets the segments field, the second show_network gets provider:physical_network and provider:network_type).

Maybe this is all too cute and over-complicated and we should just get the network once at the top with all three fields since we're going to get the network at least once in this method anyway. That would simplify things and I could decouple that as a separate patch from this more complicated one that passes in the network kwarg.

Admittedly this is a tricky statement, but the key to notice here is the "WHERE flavor.id IS NULL". This is saying only where the "flavor" table had no matching ID. You read it as load_balancer.flavor_id IS NULL".
Basically I'm looking LBs with flavor_id that no longer exists in the flavor table.
Ah, yes, there is a bug here. fixing.
It is better to use sqlalchemy query options, rather then raw sql. Have you tried using https://docs.sqlalchemy.org/en/13/orm/query.html#sqlalchemy.orm.query.Query.outerjoin for such update?

Could you post link for issues with default?
You already introduce flavor and flavor_profile table here, so it already has some complexity :)

I give my comment based on my experience working with/clearing neutron migrations in the past days.
As postgres support dropped - this is not urgent(I didn't even score with -1 this), but generally we should use sqlalchemy if it supports required operations.
I generally agree, though I don't think we need to block this on that? It's a one-time query during an upgrade, so it should be fine.

I have a couple of comments about this.
1. Remember this runs outside of the Octavia processes, meaning none of the SQLAlchemy data models are available and the ORM layer is not available. It would have to be created in this script to use the ORM query syntax. This would increase the required code and the complexity.
2. OpenStack has stopped testing databases other than mysql.
3. This is standard SQL-92 (section 7.5 covers the join syntax), so if the database doesn't support this we are going to have bigger issues using it.
4. SQLAlchemy is error and bug prone, (see issues we have had with "default" values).

That said, if you feel I should change this into SA syntax, please comment here.

I agree with Ann. It could happen this SQL query is not compatible with other DBMS like PostgreSQL (unlikely but still). It would come at the cost of operators failing run this migration that could not be fixed with a follow-up migration.

nodepool/builder.py.message:
This check was necessary because building an image will take a long time and we needed to make sure that we still had our lock on the ImageBuild. See change: I646a0f7696a9adb4dbfbb224441b9fb411c2953d

Doesn't look like we have that information now with the retry in place, so this may be a source of problems.

It would not be overwritten. We use sequences for the image builds, so the 2nd builder would get a new znode. And as long as the first builder holds a lock for that particular image build, the 2nd builder would not start trying to build the same image. If we did lose the lock, that's when we have to assume that another build for that image could be happening, so we have to mark the first one as failed (thus the reason for the check above).

Actually I don't think this matter. If builder01 lost the connection during the build, then another builder may try to build the image and both will store the image as READY. Is that really an issue?

Moreover let's consider this scenario: builder01 takes a very long time to build the image (e.g. slow disk i/o) and lost the connection during the build, it will eventually write the image state as FAILED. What happens if builder02 grab the lock, build the image faster than builder01 and write the image state as READY. Wouldn't builder01 over-write builder02 results, resulting in the image state being FAILED, even though both builder created one?

If this scenario repeats, then the image state may never be READY...
